title: John Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on John chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: John Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of John Chapter 17.

questions.question: Who did Jesus lift up his eyes to when He spoke in John 17:1?
options: Father
Peter
Moses
The disciples
questions.correctAnswer: Father
questions.explanation: John 17:1 states that Jesus lifted up his eyes to heaven and said, 'Father...'

questions.question: According to John 17:2, what power was given to Jesus?
options: Power over all flesh
Power to heal only
Power to teach
Power to build temples
questions.correctAnswer: Power over all flesh
questions.explanation: John 17:2 says that Jesus was given power over all flesh to give eternal life.

questions.question: What is eternal life according to John 17:3?
options: Knowing the only true God and Jesus Christ
Living forever on earth
Having wealth and power
Being free from sickness
questions.correctAnswer: Knowing the only true God and Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: John 17:3 defines eternal life as knowing the only true God and Jesus Christ whom He sent.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from John 17:4: 'I have finished the ______ which thou gavest me to do.'
options: work
task
command
journey
questions.correctAnswer: work
questions.explanation: John 17:4 states Jesus finished the work which God gave Him to do.

questions.question: What does Jesus ask the Father to glorify Him with in John 17:5?
options: The glory He had before the world
The glory of the temple
The glory of the earth
The glory of angels
questions.correctAnswer: The glory He had before the world
questions.explanation: John 17:5 requests glorification with the glory Jesus had with the Father before the world existed.

questions.question: True or False: In John 17:9, Jesus prays for the whole world.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 17:9 says Jesus prays not for the world, but for those given to Him by the Father.

questions.question: According to John 17:11, what does Jesus ask the Father to keep those given to Him through?
options: Thine own name
Their faith
Their hearts
The law
questions.correctAnswer: Thine own name
questions.explanation: John 17:11 requests the Father to keep them through His own name.

questions.question: Who is called the 'son of perdition' in John 17:12?
options: One lost
Judas Iscariot
Peter
John the Baptist
questions.correctAnswer: One lost
questions.explanation: John 17:12 mentions that none were lost except the son of perdition, referring to Judas Iscariot.

questions.question: True or False: John 17:14 says the world has loved Jesus' disciples.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 17:14 states the world hated the disciples because they are not of the world.

questions.question: What does Jesus ask the Father to keep the disciples from in John 17:15?
options: Evil
The world
Temptation
Sickness
questions.correctAnswer: Evil
questions.explanation: John 17:15 says Jesus prays not to take them out of the world but to keep them from evil.

questions.question: According to John 17:17, how are the disciples sanctified?
options: Through thy truth
Through sacrifices
Through prayer
Through fasting
questions.correctAnswer: Through thy truth
questions.explanation: John 17:17 states sanctification is through God's truth, and His word is truth.

questions.question: Who does Jesus say He sends into the world in John 17:18?
options: The disciples
Angels
The prophets
The Pharisees
questions.correctAnswer: The disciples
questions.explanation: John 17:18 says Jesus sends the disciples into the world as the Father sent Him.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus prays only for the disciples present with Him in John 17:20.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 17:20 shows Jesus also prays for all who will believe through their word.

questions.question: What is the purpose of all being one as stated in John 17:21?
options: That the world may believe the Father sent Jesus
That they may become wealthy
That they may live in a city
That they may be famous
questions.correctAnswer: That the world may believe the Father sent Jesus
questions.explanation: John 17:21 explains unity so the world may believe the Father sent Jesus.

questions.question: According to John 17:24, where does Jesus want those given to Him to be?
options: With Him where He is
In Jerusalem
In the wilderness
At the temple
questions.correctAnswer: With Him where He is
questions.explanation: John 17:24 expresses Jesus' desire that those given to Him be where He is to behold His glory.

medium.title: John Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from John Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about God's care through trials. Based on John 17, what biblical truth would you share about God's protection and unity among believers?
options: God prays that we be kept safe through His name and be united as one just as He is with the Father.
God promises to remove all trials immediately so we will not suffer.
God encourages believers to isolate themselves to avoid worldly troubles.
God commands believers to depend solely on their own strength in trials.
questions.correctAnswer: God prays that we be kept safe through His name and be united as one just as He is with the Father.
questions.explanation: John 17:11 shows Jesus praying for believers to be kept safe through God's name and to be one as He and the Father are one. Verses 20-21 emphasize unity so the world may believe, and verse 15 shows Jesus praying for protection from evil, not removal from the world.

questions.question: How does John 17 teach us about the importance of sharing the Gospel in daily life?
options: Jesus sent believers into the world just as the Father sent Him, to share the truth and be sanctified by it.
Believers should avoid speaking about Jesus to prevent conflict with the world.
Evangelism is optional and not emphasized in this chapter.
Only priests are responsible for sharing God's word.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus sent believers into the world just as the Father sent Him, to share the truth and be sanctified by it.
questions.explanation: John 17:18 states Jesus was sent into the world and He also sends believers into the world. Verse 19 shows Jesus sanctifies Himself so believers also might be sanctified through truth, emphasizing their mission to share the Gospel.

questions.question: A Christian wants to strengthen their faith and joy amid challenges. According to John 17, what should they focus on to experience Christ’s joy fulfilled in themselves?
options: Receiving and keeping God's word given by Jesus.
Avoiding all worldly relationships.
Relying only on personal strength without prayer.
Focusing on material blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: Receiving and keeping God's word given by Jesus.
questions.explanation: John 17:13 shows Jesus speaks so believers might have His joy fulfilled in themselves, and verses 7-8 emphasize that they have received and kept His words and believed that He was sent by the Father, linking faithfulness to joy.

questions.question: What does John 17 teach about the relationship between believers and the world?
options: Believers are not of the world just as Jesus is not of the world, and thus face hatred from it.
Believers should become part of the world to avoid conflict.
The world and believers share the same goals and values.
Believers should withdraw completely from the world.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are not of the world just as Jesus is not of the world, and thus face hatred from it.
questions.explanation: John 17:14-16 clearly states believers are not of the world just as Jesus is not, and because of this, the world hates them. This teaches believers to expect opposition but remain distinct.

questions.question: How does this passage teach us about prayer for others in the Christian life?
options: Jesus prays specifically for those given to Him and also for future believers, showing the importance of intercession.
Prayer should only be for personal needs and not for others.
Jesus prays only for Himself and not for believers.
Prayer is unnecessary since God already knows everything.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus prays specifically for those given to Him and also for future believers, showing the importance of intercession.
questions.explanation: John 17:9-10 shows Jesus praying for those given to Him, and verse 20 extends this prayer to future believers. This highlights the biblical virtue of intercessory prayer for all Christians.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to isolate from the world to avoid evil. What does John 17 teach about facing evil in the world?
options: Jesus prays not for believers to be taken out of the world, but to be protected from evil while remaining in it.
Believers should abandon the world entirely to avoid evil.
Evil will not affect believers if they stay silent.
Believers should fight evil by worldly means only.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus prays not for believers to be taken out of the world, but to be protected from evil while remaining in it.
questions.explanation: John 17:15 records Jesus praying that believers not be taken out of the world but be kept from evil, teaching a balanced approach of engagement with divine protection.

questions.question: According to John 17, what is the source of eternal life?
options: Knowing the only true God and Jesus Christ whom He has sent.
Performing good works alone.
Following religious traditions without faith.
Accumulating wealth for security.
questions.correctAnswer: Knowing the only true God and Jesus Christ whom He has sent.
questions.explanation: John 17:3 defines eternal life as knowing the only true God and Jesus Christ, emphasizing relationship and knowledge rather than works or material gain.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the work He was given to do on earth, and how does this teach us about faithful work ethic?
options: He glorified the Father and finished the work given Him, teaching faithful obedience to God's calling.
He did only part of the work and left the rest unfinished.
He worked only when convenient and rested often.
He avoided hard work to focus on personal comfort.
questions.correctAnswer: He glorified the Father and finished the work given Him, teaching faithful obedience to God's calling.
questions.explanation: John 17:4 shows Jesus stating He glorified the Father and finished the work God gave Him, modeling faithful obedience and diligence in fulfilling God's purpose.

questions.question: True or False: According to John 17, Jesus prays that believers will be sanctified through God's truth and that God's word is truth.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 17:17 states Jesus prays for believers to be sanctified through God's truth and affirms that God's word is truth, highlighting the importance of Scripture in spiritual growth.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus prays in John 17 only for His immediate disciples and not for future believers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 17:20 shows Jesus prays not only for His immediate disciples but also for those who will believe through their word, indicating His concern for all believers.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jesus prays that believers may be one, even as the Father is in me, and I in the Father, that they also may be one in us; that the world may ______ that you have sent me.
options: believe
doubt
ignore
reject
questions.correctAnswer: believe
questions.explanation: John 17:21 teaches the purpose of unity among believers is so the world may believe that God sent Jesus, emphasizing the power of Christian unity as a witness.

questions.question: Based on John 17, how should believers view their identity in relation to the world when facing opposition?
options: They are not of the world, just as Jesus is not of the world, which explains why the world may hate them.
They should conform to the world to avoid rejection.
They are part of the world and should accept all its values.
They must separate completely and reject all interaction with the world.
questions.correctAnswer: They are not of the world, just as Jesus is not of the world, which explains why the world may hate them.
questions.explanation: John 17:14-16 explains believers are distinct from the world like Jesus is, and this separation causes the world to hate them, encouraging faithful perseverance.

questions.question: What does John 17 teach about the glory believers receive from God and its purpose?
options: Jesus gives believers the glory He received from the Father so that they may be one as He and the Father are one.
Believers receive glory to boast and elevate themselves above others.
Glory is only for Jesus and not shared with believers.
Glory is a future reward not experienced in this life.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus gives believers the glory He received from the Father so that they may be one as He and the Father are one.
questions.explanation: John 17:22 describes Jesus giving believers the glory given to Him by the Father to promote unity, showing glory is meant for communal unity, not self-exaltation.

questions.question: How does John 17 instruct believers to maintain holiness and devotion in their daily walk?
options: By sanctifying themselves through God's truth and keeping His word, which is truth.
By relying solely on human wisdom and traditions.
By isolating from others and avoiding all worldly contact.
By performing rituals without understanding God's word.
questions.correctAnswer: By sanctifying themselves through God's truth and keeping His word, which is truth.
questions.explanation: John 17:17 and 19 stress sanctification through God's truth and the importance of God's word, teaching believers to remain holy by abiding in Scripture.

questions.question: According to John 17, what motivates Jesus' prayer that believers be with Him and see His glory?
options: Because the Father loved Jesus before the foundation of the world.
Because believers earned their place by works.
Because believers deserve glory more than Jesus.
Because the world demands to see His glory.
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Father loved Jesus before the foundation of the world.
questions.explanation: John 17:24 records Jesus praying that believers be with Him to behold His glory, which was given by the Father who loved Him before the world began, showing divine love as the motivation.

hard.title: John Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from John Chapter 17.

questions.question: In John 17:3, what is described as eternal life?
options: Knowing the only true God and Jesus Christ
Performing miracles in Jesus' name
Observing the Sabbath strictly
Following the laws of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Knowing the only true God and Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: John 17:3 defines eternal life as knowing the only true God and Jesus Christ, whom God has sent, highlighting the relational and revelatory aspect of eternal life.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus asking the Father to glorify Him with the glory He had before the world was, as seen in John 17:5?
options: It reveals Jesus' pre-existence and divine glory before creation
It refers to future earthly kingship over Israel
It is a metaphor for Jesus’ resurrection
It symbolizes the glory of the temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals Jesus' pre-existence and divine glory before creation
questions.explanation: John 17:5 shows Jesus requesting the restoration of His divine glory that He shared with the Father before the world existed, emphasizing His eternal divine nature.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between Jesus and the disciples according to John 17:10?
options: All Jesus' are the Father's and all the Father's are Jesus'
The disciples are independent from both Jesus and the Father
The disciples belong only to Jesus and not to the Father
Jesus has authority over the disciples but not the Father
questions.correctAnswer: All Jesus' are the Father's and all the Father's are Jesus'
questions.explanation: John 17:10 states a mutual belonging between Jesus and the Father concerning the disciples, indicating unity and shared authority.

questions.question: According to John 17:11, what is Jesus' prayer for the disciples as He prepares to leave the world?
options: That they may be kept in unity as Jesus and the Father are one
That they might become wealthy and powerful
That they be taken out of the world immediately
That they may be given political influence
questions.correctAnswer: That they may be kept in unity as Jesus and the Father are one
questions.explanation: John 17:11 reveals Jesus praying for the disciples' unity, mirroring the unity He shares with the Father, which is a key theme of this passage.

questions.question: What does Jesus mean by 'the son of perdition' in John 17:12, and how does it relate to Old Testament prophecy?
options: Refers to Judas Iscariot whose betrayal fulfills scripture
Refers to Peter's denial to fulfill prophecy
Refers to the Roman soldiers as agents of destruction
Refers to a symbolic figure of evil in Daniel
questions.correctAnswer: Refers to Judas Iscariot whose betrayal fulfills scripture
questions.explanation: John 17:12 identifies the 'son of perdition' as Judas Iscariot, whose betrayal fulfills scripture, linking this to prophetic fulfillment such as Psalm 41:9.

questions.question: In John 17:14, why does the world hate Jesus' disciples?
options: Because they are not of the world, just as Jesus is not of the world
Because they refuse to pay taxes
Because they are political revolutionaries
Because they worship different gods
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are not of the world, just as Jesus is not of the world
questions.explanation: John 17:14 explains that the disciples are hated because they do not belong to the world system, paralleling Jesus’ own separation from worldly values.

questions.question: What does Jesus ask the Father to do for His disciples in John 17:15?
options: Keep them from evil while remaining in the world
Remove them from the world immediately
Grant them earthly riches and status
Make them politically powerful
questions.correctAnswer: Keep them from evil while remaining in the world
questions.explanation: John 17:15 shows Jesus praying not for their removal from the world, but for protection from evil, indicating a mission within the world despite opposition.

questions.question: How does John 17:17 define the process of sanctification for believers?
options: Through the truth, which is God's word
Through ritual sacrifices
Through strict adherence to the Law of Moses
Through baptism only
questions.correctAnswer: Through the truth, which is God's word
questions.explanation: John 17:17 links sanctification directly with truth, specifically identifying God's word as the truth that sanctifies believers.

questions.question: What typological significance does Jesus' sending of the disciples into the world in John 17:18 have?
options: It parallels the Old Testament sending of prophets to Israel
It symbolizes the exile of Israel to Babylon
It represents the priestly service in the temple
It foreshadows the destruction of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels the Old Testament sending of prophets to Israel
questions.explanation: John 17:18 reflects a typology where Jesus, like Old Testament prophets sent by God, sends His disciples into the world to bear witness.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the unity Jesus prays for in John 17:21, and how does it reflect the divine relationship?
options: Unity among believers mirroring the unity of the Father and the Son
Political unity among Jewish tribes
Cultural unity of all nations
Unity in worship practices only
questions.correctAnswer: Unity among believers mirroring the unity of the Father and the Son
questions.explanation: John 17:21 expresses Jesus' desire for believers to share a profound spiritual unity that reflects the intimate and perfect unity between the Father and the Son.

questions.question: How does John 17:22 expand on the theme of glory given by the Father to Jesus and then to believers?
options: Jesus shares the glory given by the Father with believers to unify them
Glory is only reserved for Jesus and the Father
Believers are given glory through wealth and power
Glory refers to military victory
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus shares the glory given by the Father with believers to unify them
questions.explanation: John 17:22 indicates Jesus imparts the glory given by the Father to believers, symbolizing shared divine presence and unity.

questions.question: Which Old Testament concept does Jesus allude to in John 17:24 when He speaks of being with the Father before the foundation of the world?
options: The eternal covenant and pre-existence of the Messiah
The Exodus from Egypt
The building of Solomon’s temple
The giving of the Law at Mount Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: The eternal covenant and pre-existence of the Messiah
questions.explanation: John 17:24 alludes to the pre-existent divine nature of Jesus and the eternal love of the Father, echoing themes of the eternal covenant found in Isaiah and Psalms.

questions.question: True or False: According to John 17:20, Jesus prays only for the disciples present with Him and not for future believers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 17:20 explicitly states Jesus prays not only for the current disciples but also for those who will believe through their message.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'sanctify myself' in John 17:19 imply about Jesus' role in the sanctification of believers?
options: Jesus dedicates Himself so believers may be made holy through truth
Jesus performs ritual purification for the temple
Jesus separates Himself from sinners physically
Jesus declares Himself as a priest
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus dedicates Himself so believers may be made holy through truth
questions.explanation: John 17:19 indicates Jesus consecrates or sets Himself apart for the purpose of sanctifying believers through truth, highlighting His mediating role.

questions.question: How does the prayer in John 17 emphasize the theme of love as a theological motif?
options: By focusing on the love between the Father and the Son extended to believers
By emphasizing love as an ethical command only
By discussing love as a political alliance
By restricting love to the Jewish people alone
questions.correctAnswer: By focusing on the love between the Father and the Son extended to believers
questions.explanation: John 17:26 shows Jesus declaring the love of the Father for Him extended to believers, making love a central relational and theological motif in the prayer.

theological.title: John Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from John Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to John 17:3, what is the essence of eternal life?
options: To know the only true God and Jesus Christ whom He sent
To obey all commandments perfectly
To live forever in heaven
To have faith that Jesus will return
questions.correctAnswer: To know the only true God and Jesus Christ whom He sent
questions.explanation: John 17:3 explicitly states eternal life is to know the only true God and Jesus Christ whom He sent. This reflects Old Testament teachings like Deuteronomy 6:4 and New Testament affirmations such as 1 John 5:20, emphasizing personal knowledge and relationship with God as the foundation of eternal life.

questions.question: In John 17:1, Jesus asks the Father to glorify Him so that He may glorify the Father. What does this reveal about the relationship between the Father and the Son?
options: They mutually glorify each other
The Father is superior and only glorifies the Son
The Son glorifies the Father alone without reciprocation
They operate independently
questions.correctAnswer: They mutually glorify each other
questions.explanation: John 17:1 shows mutual glorification, reflecting the divine unity and eternal honor between Father and Son, consistent with John 1:14 and Philippians 2:9-11, revealing the co-equal nature of the Son and the Father.

questions.question: What power has the Father given to Jesus according to John 17:2?
options: Power over all flesh to give eternal life to those given to Him
Power to judge angels
Power to create new heavens and earth
Power to control natural elements
questions.correctAnswer: Power over all flesh to give eternal life to those given to Him
questions.explanation: John 17:2 explains that the Father gave Jesus authority over all people to grant eternal life to those given to Him. This is consistent with biblical teaching in Acts 10:42 and Romans 5:17 about Christ's authority to grant eternal life.

questions.question: What does Jesus claim to have completed in John 17:4?
options: The work the Father gave Him to do
Building the temple
Writing the scriptures
Raising the dead
questions.correctAnswer: The work the Father gave Him to do
questions.explanation: John 17:4 states Jesus glorified the Father on earth by completing the work given by the Father. This aligns with His obedience theme in Philippians 2:8 and fulfillment of prophecy in Isaiah 53:10.

questions.question: According to John 17:5, what does Jesus ask the Father to do after completing His earthly mission?
options: Glorify Him with the glory He had before the world existed
Send an angel to protect His followers
Provide Him with a kingdom on earth
Raise Him from the dead
questions.correctAnswer: Glorify Him with the glory He had before the world existed
questions.explanation: John 17:5 reveals Jesus asking to be glorified with the divine glory He shared with the Father before creation, affirming His pre-existence and divine nature as in John 1:1 and Hebrews 1:3.

questions.question: In John 17:11, what is Jesus' prayer for His disciples concerning their unity?
options: That they may be one as the Father and Son are one
That they may have wealth and prosperity
That they may be protected from all physical harm
That they may become rulers of nations
questions.correctAnswer: That they may be one as the Father and Son are one
questions.explanation: John 17:11 emphasizes Jesus praying for the unity of His followers mirroring the unity between Father and Son. This unity is essential for the Church’s witness as supported by Ephesians 4:3-6 and Psalm 133:1.

questions.question: John 17:14 states the world hated Jesus’ followers because they are not of the world, just as Jesus is not of the world. What theological truth does this express?
options: Believers are distinct from worldly values and systems
Believers should dominate worldly governments
Believers will be physically separated from the world immediately
Believers must reject all forms of culture
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are distinct from worldly values and systems
questions.explanation: John 17:14 teaches that Christian believers are called to be distinct from worldly values, which causes hostility. This separation is spiritual and ethical, consistent with Romans 12:2 and 1 John 2:15-16.

questions.question: What does Jesus request in John 17:15 regarding His disciples and their experience in the world?
options: That they may be kept from evil but remain in the world
That they be taken out of the world
That they receive worldly riches
That they be hidden from all persecution
questions.correctAnswer: That they may be kept from evil but remain in the world
questions.explanation: John 17:15 shows Jesus praying for protection from evil while His disciples remain in the world to fulfill their mission. This aligns with Paul’s instruction in Ephesians 6:10-18 and Jesus’ own teaching in Matthew 10:16-18.

questions.question: How does Jesus describe the relationship between His followers and the Father in John 17:10?
options: All that belongs to Jesus also belongs to the Father and vice versa
They are servants with no direct access to God
They belong only to Jesus, not the Father
They are independent of both Jesus and the Father
questions.correctAnswer: All that belongs to Jesus also belongs to the Father and vice versa
questions.explanation: John 17:10 reveals the perfect unity and shared possession between Father and Son, extending to the followers. This mutual belonging is a deep theological statement of divine unity and relational intimacy, supported in John 10:30 and Colossians 1:17.

questions.question: According to John 17:23, what is the purpose of the unity Jesus prays for among believers?
options: That the world may know the Father sent Jesus and loved believers as He loved Jesus
That believers might gain political power
That believers may accumulate wealth
That believers avoid suffering
questions.correctAnswer: That the world may know the Father sent Jesus and loved believers as He loved Jesus
questions.explanation: John 17:23 shows unity among believers serves as a testimony to the world of Jesus’ divine mission and God’s love, echoing themes in John 13:35 and Matthew 5:16 about witness through love and unity.

questions.question: What does Jesus mean by sanctifying Himself in John 17:19 for the sake of His followers?
options: He consecrates Himself to God’s purpose so they may be sanctified in truth
He separates Himself physically from the world
He gains holiness through human effort
He removes Himself from all suffering
questions.correctAnswer: He consecrates Himself to God’s purpose so they may be sanctified in truth
questions.explanation: John 17:19 indicates Jesus’ self-sanctification is His dedication to God’s redemptive plan, enabling believers to be sanctified by truth. This aligns with Hebrews 10:10 and 1 Peter 1:15-16, where sanctification is God’s work through Christ.

questions.question: In John 17:20-21, Jesus prays not only for His current disciples but also for those who will believe through their message. What does this reveal about the scope of His intercession?
options: It extends to all future believers, ensuring their unity
It is limited to the twelve apostles only
It excludes those outside Israel
It focuses only on the immediate disciples present
questions.correctAnswer: It extends to all future believers, ensuring their unity
questions.explanation: John 17:20-21 shows Jesus’ intercession is inclusive of all future believers, emphasizing the continuity and unity of the Church throughout history. This is consistent with Ephesians 1:18-23 and Hebrews 7:25.

questions.question: What attribute of God is emphasized by Jesus when He says in John 17:17 'Sanctify them through thy truth: thy word is truth'?
options: God’s word is the ultimate standard of truth and sanctification
God changes His word according to circumstances
God’s truth is relative
God’s truth is unknown
questions.correctAnswer: God’s word is the ultimate standard of truth and sanctification
questions.explanation: John 17:17 highlights the absolute and sanctifying nature of God’s word as truth. This is foundational in biblical theology as echoed in Psalm 119:160 and 2 Timothy 3:16.

questions.question: According to John 17:24, what desire does Jesus express regarding those given to Him by the Father?
options: That they may be with Him and behold His glory
That they may inherit earthly kingdoms
That they may be exempt from trials
That they may remain anonymous
questions.correctAnswer: That they may be with Him and behold His glory
questions.explanation: John 17:24 shows Jesus’ desire for believers to be with Him and see His divine glory, indicating eternal fellowship. This echoes promises in Revelation 21:3-4 and 2 Corinthians 4:6.

questions.question: In John 17:6, Jesus states He has manifested the Father's name to the men given to Him. What does this imply about Jesus’ mission?
options: To reveal God’s character and truth to the chosen people
To establish a political kingdom
To keep God’s name secret
To replace the Father’s name with His own
questions.correctAnswer: To reveal God’s character and truth to the chosen people
questions.explanation: John 17:6 indicates Jesus’ mission is revelatory, making God's name known to those given to Him, consistent with John 1:18 and Exodus 3:13-15 where God’s name signifies His nature and presence.
